review.title: Data-Intensive Supercomputing in the Cloud: Global Analytics for Satellite Imagery
review.abstract: We present our experiences using cloud computing to support data-intensive analytics on satellite imagery for commercial applications. Drawing from our background in high-performance computing, we draw parallels between the early days of clustered computing systems and the current state of cloud computing and its potential to disrupt the HPC market. Using our own virtual file system layer on top of cloud remote object storage, we demonstrate aggregate read bandwidth of 230 gigabytes per second using 512 Google Compute Engine (GCE) nodes accessing a USA multi-region standard storage bucket. This figure is comparable to the best HPC storage systems in existence. We also present several of our application results, including the identification of field boundaries in Ukraine, and the generation of a global cloud-free base layer from Landsat imagery.

sections.heading: B. Field segmentation
sections.text: The analysis of satellite images taken at the pixel level fails due to an obvious source of additional information. The results of such an analysis should be highly spatially correlated, as nearby pixels are likely to have the same land use. In the case of agriculture in particular, the land is divided into fields planted with the same crop and subsequently subjected to very similar conditions. Thus, identifying the pixels belonging to the same fields leads to improved analysis results. Figure 4 shows the segmentation into fields of one of our UTM tiles covering a part of the Kherson Oblast in southern Ukraine that borders the Dnieper River. The tile is 6144 x 6144 pixels at a resolution of 10 m. Segmentation is produced by multispectral images from NASA Landscape 7 and Landsat 8 satellites collected since 2011, as well as from the ESA Sentinel 2A satellites collected since the beginning of their mission in June 2015.

sections.heading: C. Cloud-free composite images
sections.text: We used the virtual file system described above to create a 15-meter-long, cloud-free composite image of the world using all of Landsat 8 "s pre-September 2016 data (Figure 5).The input for this calculation consists of 68 TB of JPEG 2000-compressed images and includes 3.4 years of Earth observation, the output being a weighted average of these images, with a higher emphasis on cloud-free, green input images. Work was slightly paralleled by dividing the Earth's surface into 43k square tiles, each tile being processed independently, and distributed over 400 32-vCPU-preemptive instances, taking 8 hours, for a total of 100k CPU hours and costing $1000.A similar composite image was announced by the Google Maps team in 2016 at https: / / maps.googleblog.com / 2016 / 06 / keep-earth-date-looking.html. sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: While accelerated architectures are being explored in the exa-scale race with the associated disruption of established software interfaces, the cloud offers an alternative convergent architecture that can exploit economies of scale and continue to protect application investments across generations of hardware. While Landsat took more than 40 years to collect one petabyte of data, the planet's satellite constellation [5] will produce many petabytes next year. In this work, we have shown that cloud computing architectures are suitable for at least one important class of data-intensive scientific analysis.
